Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and stir just until combined. Do not overmix.
Fold in the chopped pecans, distributing them evenly throughout the batter.
Divide the batter evenly among the three prepared cans or loaf pans, filling each about two-thirds full.
Bake for 60–70 minutes, or until a toothpick or skewer inserted in the center comes out clean.
Let the loaves cool in the cans or pans for 10–15 minutes, then carefully turn out onto a wire rack to cool completely.
Wrap the cooled loaves in plastic wrap or foil and let rest overnight for easier slicing and richer flavor.

original_recipe.name: Waffles
instructions: Sift flour, baking powder, and salt together.
Beat egg yolks, add milk and oil. Add this to the flour mixture.
Beat egg whites until stiff; fold into batter.
Bake in waffle iron until golden brown.

improved_recipe.name: Classic Light and Fluffy Waffles
instructions: Preheat your waffle iron according to the manufacturer's instructions.
In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, salt, and sugar (if using).
Separate the eggs, placing the whites in a clean bowl and the yolks in another.
Beat the egg yolks lightly, then whisk in the milk and vegetable oil.
Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and stir just until combined. Some lumps are okay.
In a separate bowl, beat the egg whites with an electric mixer until stiff peaks form.
Gently fold the beaten egg whites into the batter using a rubber spatula. Do not overmix.
Pour the batter onto the preheated waffle iron (amount will vary by waffle maker size).
Cook until the waffles are golden brown and crisp, usually 3-5 minutes depending on your waffle iron.
Serve immediately with butter, syrup, fresh fruit, or your favorite toppings.

original_recipe.name: Cinnamon Rolls
instructions: Sift two cups of the flour and the yeast together into a large bowl. Mix well.
Heat milk, water, sugar, oil and salt over low heat until warm, stirring to dissolve the sugar.
Add liquids to flour-yeast mixture and beat until smooth (two to three minutes with an electric mixer, 300 strokes by hand).
Mix in egg whites.
Add one more cup of flour and beat for another minute.
Add more flour and continue to beat until the dough is too stiff to continue.
Turn out onto a floured board and knead for eight to ten minutes, adding remaining flour as needed.
Do not stint on the kneading time as it is necessary to develop the gluten.
Form the dough into a ball and place it into a bowl coated with a nonstick vegetable spray.
Cover, and let rise in the oven at 80° to 85° F, until doubled in bulk (takes one and one-half to two hours).
Punch down the dough and let it rest for ten minutes.
Then roll dough out to a thickness of from 1/2 to 3/4 inch.
Brush or spread with melted margarine and sprinkle with cinnamon and sugar.
Roll up (like a jelly roll) and cut crosswise at a thickness of 1 inch or as desired.
Leaving space between the rolls for them to rise, place them into pans coated with a nonstick vegetable spray, and spray tops with Pam.
Let rise again until doubled in size (this will take from thirty to forty-five minutes).
Bake in a pre-heated 375° F oven for twenty to twenty-five minutes, depending on size.
Glaze with powdered sugar.

improved_recipe.name: Homemade Cinnamon Rolls
instructions: In a large bowl, combine 2 cups flour with the yeast and mix well.
In a small saucepan, heat the milk, water, 1/2 cup sugar, oil, and salt over low heat until warm (120-130°F), stirring to dissolve the sugar.
Pour the warm liquid into the flour-yeast mixture. Beat with an electric mixer for 2-3 minutes until smooth.
Beat in the egg whites until incorporated.
Add 1 more cup of flour and beat for 1 minute.
Gradually stir in enough of the remaining flour to make a dough that is too stiff to stir.
Turn the dough out onto a floured surface and knead for 8-10 minutes, adding flour as needed, until smooth and elastic.
Place the dough in a greased bowl, turning to coat. Cover and let rise in a warm place (80-85°F) until doubled, about 1 1/2-2 hours.
Punch down the dough and let rest for 10 minutes.
Roll the dough into a large rectangle, about 1/2-inch thick.
Brush the dough generously with melted margarine or butter.
Mix the brown sugar and cinnamon together and sprinkle evenly over the buttered dough.
Starting from a long edge, roll the dough tightly into a log. Cut into 1-inch slices.
Place the rolls in greased 9x13-inch pans, leaving space between them. Spray the tops lightly with cooking spray.
Cover and let rise until doubled, 30-45 minutes.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Bake for 20-25 minutes, or until golden brown.
While the rolls bake, make the glaze by whisking together confectioners' sugar and enough milk to make a drizzling consistency.
Drizzle the glaze over warm rolls and serve.

original_recipe.name: Cornmeal Yeast Rolls
instructions: Dissolve yeast in warm water in a large bowl; let stand five minutes.
Combine milk, sugar, oil, margarine and salt in a saucepan; heat until margarine melts, then mix well. Cool to 105° F to 115° F.
Add milk mixture to yeast mixture.
Stir in egg substitute, cornmeal, and two cups of flour.
Beat at medium speed with an electric mixer until smooth.
Stir in enough of the remaining flour to make a soft dough.
Turn dough out onto a lightly floured surface and knead until smooth (about eight minutes).
Place in a bowl coated with a butter flavored nonstick vegetable spray, turn and coat the top.
Cover, and let rise in a warm place (85°F) until doubled (one hour).
Punch dough down; shape into 36 balls.
Place balls on cookie sheet lightly coated with spray.
Let rise in a warm place for forty-five minutes or until doubled.
Bake at 375° F for 12 to 15 minutes or until golden.
Coat rolls with spray; remove from pan immediately.

improved_recipe.name: Golden Cornmeal Dinner Rolls
instructions: In a large bowl, dissolve the yeast in warm water. Let stand for 5 minutes until foamy.
In a small saucepan, heat the milk, sugar, oil, margarine, and salt over low heat until the margarine melts. Stir well and cool to 105-115°F.
Add the cooled milk mixture to the yeast mixture.
Stir in the egg substitute, cornmeal, and 2 cups of the flour.
Beat with an electric mixer on medium speed for 2 minutes until smooth.
Gradually stir in enough of the remaining flour to form a soft dough.
Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface and knead for about 8 minutes, adding flour as needed, until smooth and elastic.
Place the dough in a greased bowl, turning to coat all sides. Cover and let rise in a warm place (about 85°F) until doubled in size, about 1 hour.
Punch down the dough and divide into 36 equal pieces. Shape each piece into a smooth ball.
Place the balls on greased or parchment-lined baking sheets, spacing them about 2 inches apart.
Cover and let rise in a warm place for 45 minutes, or until doubled in size.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Bake for 12-15 minutes, or until the rolls are golden brown.
Brush the hot rolls lightly with melted butter or spray with butter-flavored cooking spray.
Remove from the pans immediately and serve warm.

original_recipe.name: Basic Sweet Dough
instructions: Sift two cups of the flour and the yeast together into a large bowl. Mix well.
Heat milk, water, sugar, oil and salt over low heat until warm, stirring to dissolve the sugar.
Add liquids to flour-yeast mixture and beat until smooth (two to three minutes with an electric mixer, 300 strokes by hand).
Mix in egg whites. Add one more cup of flour and beat for another minute.
Add more flour and continue to beat until the dough is too stiff to continue.
Turn out onto a floured board and knead for eight to ten minutes, adding remaining flour as needed. Do not stint on the kneading time as it is necessary to develop the gluten.
Form the dough into a ball and place in a bowl coated with a nonstick vegetable spray. Cover, and let rise in a warm place (80° to 85° F), until doubled in bulk (one and one-half to two hours).
Punch down the dough and let it rest for ten minutes.
Shape into rolls, buns, wreaths, etc. Place into pans coated with a nonstick vegetable spray, and brush tops with oil.
Cover and let rise again until doubled (thirty to forty-five minutes).
Bake in a pre-heated 350° F oven for twenty to twenty-five minutes, depending on size.

improved_recipe.name: Basic Sweet Dough
instructions: In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of the flour with the yeast. Whisk together to distribute the yeast evenly.

In a small saucepan, combine the milk, water, sugar, 1/3 cup oil, and salt. Warm over low heat, stirring occasionally, until the mixture reaches 120–130°F and the sugar dissolves. It should feel warm but not hot to the touch.

Pour the warm liquid into the flour-yeast mixture. Beat with an electric mixer on low speed for 30 seconds, scraping the bowl frequently, then beat on high speed for 2–3 minutes until smooth. (Or beat vigorously by hand for about 300 strokes.)
Add the egg whites and beat until incorporated.
Mix in 1 more cup of flour and beat for 1 minute.
Gradually stir in enough of the remaining flour (about 1 1/2 to 2 cups) to make a dough that is too stiff to stir.

Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface. Knead for 8–10 minutes, adding small amounts of flour as needed, until the dough is smooth, elastic, and no longer sticky. Proper kneading develops the gluten and creates a light, airy texture.
Shape the dough into a ball. Place it in a large bowl lightly coated with nonstick spray or oil. Turn the dough once to coat the surface. Cover with a clean kitchen towel or plastic wrap.

Let the dough rise in a warm, draft-free place (80–85°F) until doubled in size, about 1 1/2 to 2 hours. To test, gently press two fingers into the dough; if the indentation remains, the dough is ready.
Punch down the dough to release the air. Let it rest for 10 minutes.
Shape the dough as desired: rolls, buns, cinnamon rolls, coffee cakes, or loaves. Place shaped dough into pans coated with nonstick spray. Lightly brush the tops with oil to prevent drying.
Cover and let rise again in a warm place until nearly doubled in size, 30–45 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C).
Bake for 20–25 minutes (rolls and buns) or 30–35 minutes (loaves), until golden brown. The bread should sound hollow when tapped on the bottom.
Remove from pans and let cool on a wire rack. Serve warm or at room temperature.

original_recipe.name: Dinner Rolls
original_recipe.subtitle: Alma Finken Carle
instructions: Sift together about 1/3 of the flour and all of the yeast.
Heat milk, oil, sugar and salt over low heat until hot to the finger, but no more. Stir to dissolve sugar and salt.
Add liquids to the flour-yeast mixture and beat with an electric mixer at medium speed for two minutes, or 300 strokes by hand.
Add another one-half to one cup of flour and beat for another minute with the electric mixer.
Stir in enough more flour to make a soft dough.
Turn onto a floured board and knead until smooth and elastic (eight to ten minutes).
Place in a bowl that has been coated with a nonstick vegetable spray. Spray the top of the mixture with the nonstick vegetable spray. Cover with wax paper and over that place a dry cloth.
Put in a warm place (80° to 85° F), free from drafts, and let rise until doubled (about one hour).
Punch dough down. Turn out onto a floured board again and shape into any desired form.
Place rolls on baking sheets that have been lightly coated with a nonstick vegetable spray, or in muffin cups and let rise again until doubled (takes one to one & one-half hours).
Pre-heat oven to 425° F. Bake for about ten minutes and serve piping hot.

improved_recipe.name: Classic Dinner Rolls
instructions: In a large bowl, combine about 1 cup of the flour with the yeast. Whisk together to distribute the yeast evenly.

In a small saucepan, combine the milk, oil, sugar, and salt. Heat over low heat, stirring occasionally, until warm to the touch (110-115°F) and the sugar and salt dissolve. The mixture should feel warm but not hot.
Pour the warm liquid into the flour-yeast mixture. Beat with an electric mixer at medium speed for 2 minutes, or beat vigorously by hand for about 300 strokes, until smooth.
Add 1/2 to 1 cup more flour and beat for an additional 1 minute.
Gradually stir in enough of the remaining flour (about 1 1/2 to 2 cups) to form a soft dough that pulls away from the sides of the bowl.
Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface. Knead for 8-10 minutes, adding small amounts of flour as needed, until the dough is smooth, elastic, and no longer sticky.
Lightly coat a large bowl with nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl and turn once to coat. Cover with plastic wrap or a damp towel.
Let the dough rise in a warm, draft-free place (80-85°F) until doubled in size, about 1 hour. To test, gently press two fingers into the dough; if the indentation remains, it's ready.
Punch down the dough to release the air. Turn out onto a lightly floured surface and shape into desired forms: round rolls, cloverleaf, Parker House, crescents, etc.
Place shaped rolls on lightly greased baking sheets or in muffin tins, spacing them about 2 inches apart. Cover and let rise again until nearly doubled, 1 to 1 1/2 hours.
Preheat the oven to 425°F (220°C).
Bake for 10-12 minutes, or until the rolls are golden brown on top.
Serve piping hot with butter. Store leftovers in an airtight container for up to 3 days, or freeze for up to 1 month.

original_recipe.name: Crumble Coffee Cake #2
instructions: Make up batch of Basic Sweet Dough (see separate recipe). The dough should be the consistency of a thick cake batter.
There should be enough dough to make four or five eight inch square coffee cakes, 3/8" thick when first put into pan and before rising.
Pans should be coated with a nonstick vegetable spray before they are used.
For crumbles topping: Work flour into mixture of sugar, vanilla, eggs, margarine, and baking powder until crumbles form. They should be random size with largest about the size of a blueberry.
Put crumbles on top of cakes before rising, and let rise for about one hour.
Bake at 375° F for 20 to 25 minutes.

improved_recipe.name: Crumble Coffee Cake with Sweet Dough Base

ingredients.notes: prepared to thick batter consistency (see Basic Sweet Dough recipe)

instructions: Prepare one full batch of Basic Sweet Dough according to the recipe, but add a bit more liquid so the dough reaches a thick cake batter consistency rather than a standard bread dough texture.
Coat 4 to 5 eight-inch square baking pans with nonstick cooking spray.
Divide the dough evenly among the pans. Spread to about 3/8-inch thickness (it will rise during proofing). The dough should cover the bottom of each pan.
Prepare the crumble topping: In a medium bowl, combine the sugar, vanilla, eggs (or egg substitute), softened margarine, and baking powder. Mix until well blended.
Gradually work in the flour, mixing and rubbing the mixture between your fingers until crumbles form. The crumbles should vary in size, with the largest about the size of a blueberry.
Sprinkle the crumble topping evenly over each unbaked coffee cake, distributing it as uniformly as possible.
Cover the pans lightly and let the cakes rise in a warm place for about 1 hour, or until noticeably puffy.
Preheat the oven to 375°F (190°C).
Bake for 20-25 minutes, or until the cakes are golden brown and the crumble topping is lightly crisped.
Cool in the pans for 10 minutes, then cut into squares and serve warm or at room temperature. Excellent with coffee or tea!

original_recipe.name: Stöllen
original_recipe.subtitle: Alma Finken Carle Recipe

ingredients.item: Candied fruit and/or seeded Muscat raisins

instructions: Set sponge using one cup of flour, milk (cooled to lukewarm) and yeast. Mix well, cover and set in warm place to become light.
Put fruit, raisins and grated lemon rinds in a bowl. Pour rosewater and rum over this. Cover and set aside.
In a large mixing bowl, cream the softened margarine and sugar. Add the eggs, one at a time and mix well.
Put the remaining flour and salt in a large container. Make a 'hollow' in the flour and add the margarine mixture and the sponge and fruit mixtures. Mix well by hand, adding more flour if necessary.
Knead until not too sticky. Let rise in a warm place until light.
Divide into six 'half loaves'. Shape into round lumps and flatten.
Spread with reserved melted margarine, then sugar and nuts. Fold over and place in baking pan.
Pat top with melted margarine and place in a warm place to rise.
Bake in moderate oven at 350° F for forty to sixty minutes.

improved_recipe.name: Traditional German Stöllen (Alma's Recipe)

ingredients.item: Candied fruit mix and/or Muscat raisins

instructions: Scald the milk and let it cool to lukewarm (110°F). In a medium bowl, combine 1 cup of the flour, the lukewarm milk, and the yeast. Mix well, cover, and set in a warm place to rise until light and bubbly, about 30-45 minutes.
Meanwhile, combine the candied fruit, raisins, and grated lemon zest in a bowl. Pour the rosewater and rum over the fruit mixture. Cover and set aside to macerate.
In a large mixing bowl, cream together the softened margarine (reserving 3 tablespoons) and 1 cup sugar until light and fluffy. Add the eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition.

In a very large bowl or on a clean work surface, place the remaining 7 cups of flour and the salt. Make a well in the center. Add the creamed margarine mixture, the yeast sponge, and the fruit mixture (including any liquid). Mix well by hand, working the ingredients together and adding a bit more flour if the dough is too sticky.

Knead the dough on a lightly floured surface for about 8-10 minutes, until smooth and not too sticky. Place in a greased bowl, cover, and let rise in a warm place until doubled in size, about 1-2 hours.
Punch down the dough and divide it into 6 equal portions. Shape each portion into a round lump, then flatten slightly into an oval.
Melt the reserved 3 tablespoons of margarine. Brush each oval with melted margarine, then sprinkle with sugar and chopped almonds. Fold each oval in half lengthwise and place in a greased baking pan.
Brush the tops with additional melted margarine. Cover and let rise in a warm place until puffy, about 45-60 minutes.
Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Bake for 40-60 minutes, or until golden brown and the bread sounds hollow when tapped. If the tops brown too quickly, tent with foil.
Cool on wire racks. Dust with powdered sugar before serving if desired. Stöllen keeps well and improves with age when wrapped tightly.

original_recipe.name: Stöllen (Kanis Recipe)
instructions: Soak fruit and sugar in 1/2 cup whiskey overnight. Add nuts the next morning.
Cream butter, eggs, salt, and sugar together, add rest of the ingredients.
Use enough flour to make a stiff dough.
Let dough rise slowly for a long time (overnight).
Handle dough carefully, roll out lightly, cut into 1 1/2 pound pieces and tuck under.
Let rise again before baking.
Bake at 325° F for one hour.
When baked, brush top with melted butter or margarine. Then rub almond flavored sugar on top.

improved_recipe.name: Traditional German Stöllen (Kanis Family Recipe)

ingredients.notes: use 1 1/2 lbs for less sweet version

ingredients.item: Mixed candied fruit (cherries, citron, lemon peel, orange peel, pineapple)

instructions: The night before: In a large bowl, combine all the candied fruit, raisins (if using), and sugar. Pour 1/2 cup whiskey over the mixture, stir well, cover, and let macerate overnight.
The next morning: Add the chopped almonds and pecans to the fruit mixture.
In a very large mixing bowl, cream together the butter, eggs, salt, and remaining sugar until well combined.
Warm the milk to lukewarm (110°F) and dissolve the yeast in it. Let stand for 5 minutes until foamy.
Add the yeast mixture, the fruit-nut mixture, lemon zest, rosewater, and almond extract to the creamed butter mixture. Mix well.
Gradually add flour, starting with about 7 pounds, mixing and kneading until you have a stiff dough that is smooth but not sticky. Add more flour as needed, up to 12 pounds total.
Cover the dough and let it rise slowly in a cool place for a long time—overnight is ideal. The slow rise develops flavor.
The next day, turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface. Handle gently. Roll or pat out lightly to about 1 inch thickness.
Cut the dough into portions of about 1 1/2 pounds each. Shape each portion into a loaf by folding and tucking the edges under.
Place the loaves on greased baking sheets. Cover and let rise again until puffy, about 1-2 hours.
Preheat oven to 325°F (165°C). Bake for about 1 hour, or until golden brown and the loaves sound hollow when tapped.
While still hot, brush the tops with melted butter or margarine. Mix some powdered sugar with almond extract and rub this almond-flavored sugar on top of each loaf.
Cool completely before slicing. Stöllen improves with age and can be stored for weeks when wrapped tightly.

original_recipe.name: Dinner Roll Shapes
original_recipe.subtitle: Cloverleaf, Crescents, Parkerhouse, and Fantans

ingredients.notes: such as Basic Sweet Dough or Dinner Rolls

instructions: Cloverleaf Rolls: Form dough into little balls about 1/2" in diameter. Coat with a nonstick vegetable spray and place three balls in each muffin cup for each cloverleaf.

Crescents: Roll out the dough to a scant 1/4" thickness. Cut wedges from a six inch circle. Or, roll dough into a rectangle three inches wide, cut into squares, and make triangles by slicing diagonally. Brush with butter flavored oil, or margarine. Roll up the triangles, starting with the wide end, and curve into crescents.

Parkerhouse Rolls: Roll dough out to a thickness of 1/4". Cut with a three inch biscuit cutter. Make a depression with a spoon just below the center of each circle. Brush with margarine or coat with a butter flavored nonstick vegetable spray, and fold over from the top envelope fashion. The lower part with the depression should be larger than the upper portion.

Fantans: Roll out the dough into an 1/8" thick rectangle. Cut into one-inch strips. Brush with margarine or coat with butter flavored nonstick vegetable spray. Pile six or seven strips one on top of the other. Cut pieces about 1 & 1/4" long and place in muffin cups (that have been coated with a nonstick vegetable spray) with the cut sides up. They will open out in a fan shape as they bake.

improved_recipe.name: Dinner Roll Shapes (Cloverleaf, Crescents, etc.)

ingredients.notes: from Basic Sweet Dough or Dinner Rolls recipe

instructions: Prepare your favorite dinner roll dough recipe and let it rise until doubled.
Punch down the dough and divide as needed for the shapes you wish to make.

FOR CLOVERLEAF ROLLS: Pinch off small pieces of dough and roll into balls about 1/2 inch in diameter. Lightly spray muffin cups with nonstick spray. Place 3 balls in each muffin cup to form a cloverleaf shape. Let rise until doubled, then bake at 375°F (190°C) for 12-15 minutes until golden.

FOR CRESCENT ROLLS: Roll dough to 1/4-inch thickness. Cut into 6-inch circles, then cut each circle into 6 wedges (or roll into a 3-inch-wide rectangle and cut into triangles). Brush with melted margarine. Starting at the wide end, roll up each triangle and curve into a crescent shape. Place on greased baking sheet, let rise until doubled, then bake at 375°F (190°C) for 12-15 minutes.

FOR PARKERHOUSE ROLLS: Roll dough to 1/4-inch thickness. Cut with a 3-inch biscuit cutter. Use a spoon handle to make a crease just below center of each circle. Brush with margarine. Fold the top half over the bottom half (bottom should be slightly larger). Place on greased baking sheet, let rise until doubled, then bake at 375°F (190°C) for 12-15 minutes.

FOR FANTAN ROLLS: Roll dough into a rectangle 1/8-inch thick. Cut into 1-inch-wide strips. Brush with melted margarine. Stack 6-7 strips on top of each other. Cut the stack into 1 1/4-inch pieces. Place each piece cut-side up in greased muffin cups. Let rise until doubled, then bake at 375°F (190°C) for 12-15 minutes.
All shapes should be golden brown when done. Brush with additional butter if desired while still warm.

original_recipe.name: Cornbread Southern Style
instructions: Preheat oven to 425°F.
In a large bowl, combine cornmeal, flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt.
In another bowl, whisk together buttermilk, eggs, and oil.
Pour wet ingredients into dry ingredients and stir just until combined.
Pour into greased 9-inch square baking pan.
Bake 20-25 minutes until golden brown and toothpick comes out clean.

improved_recipe.name: Southern Style Buttermilk Cornbread
instructions: Preheat oven to 425°F (220°C). Grease a 9-inch square baking pan or coat with nonstick spray.
In a large mixing bowl, whisk together the cornmeal, flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt.
In a separate bowl, whisk together the buttermilk, beaten eggs, and vegetable oil until well combined.
Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and stir with a wooden spoon just until moistened. Do not overmix; the batter should be slightly lumpy.
Pour the batter into the prepared pan and spread evenly.
Bake for 20-25 minutes, or until the top is golden brown and a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean.
Let cool in the pan for 5 minutes, then cut into squares.
Serve warm with butter, honey, or alongside chili, beans, or Southern-style greens.
This cornbread is best eaten the day it's made but can be stored in an airtight container for up to 2 days.

original_recipe.name: Cornbread Revised 12.24.95
original_recipe.subtitle: Revised recipe from December 1995
instructions: Preheat oven to 400°F.
Mix dry ingredients in bowl.
In separate bowl, whisk together buttermilk, egg, and oil.
Combine wet and dry ingredients, stirring just until moistened.
Pour into greased 8-inch square pan.
Bake 20-22 minutes until golden.

improved_recipe.name: Cornbread (Revised December 24, 1995)
instructions: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Grease an 8-inch square baking pan or coat with nonstick spray.
In a large bowl, whisk together the cornmeal, flour, sugar, baking powder, baking soda, and salt.
In a separate bowl, whisk together the buttermilk, egg, and vegetable oil until well combined.
Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and stir just until combined. Do not overmix; some small lumps are okay.
Pour the batter into the prepared pan and spread evenly.
Bake for 20-22 minutes, or until the top is golden brown and a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean.
Let cool for 5 minutes before cutting into squares.
Serve warm with butter or as a side to soups, chilis, and stews.
Note: This recipe was revised on December 24, 1995 for improved texture and flavor.

original_recipe.name: Dinner Rolls and Shapes
original_recipe.subtitle: Complete recipe with multiple shaping options
instructions: Dissolve yeast in warm water. Add sugar, salt, margarine, egg, and 2 cups flour. Beat until smooth.
Stir in enough remaining flour to make dough easy to handle.
Turn dough onto lightly floured surface; knead until smooth and elastic, about 5 minutes.
Place in greased bowl; turn greased side up. Cover; let rise in warm place until double, about 1 hour.
Punch down dough. Shape into desired forms:
- Cloverleaf: Form into 1/2" balls, place 3 in each greased muffin cup
- Crescents: Roll into circles, cut into wedges, brush with margarine, roll from wide end, curve into crescents
- Parkerhouse: Cut with 3" cutter, make crease below center, brush with margarine, fold over
- Fantans: Roll into rectangle, cut into 1" strips, brush with margarine, stack 6-7 strips, cut into 1 & 1/4" pieces, place in muffin cups cut side up
Let rise until double, about 30 minutes.
Bake at 375°F for 12-15 minutes until golden brown.

improved_recipe.name: Dinner Rolls with Various Shapes
instructions: In a large bowl, dissolve the yeast in warm water. Let stand 5 minutes until foamy.
Add the sugar, salt, softened margarine, egg, and 2 cups of the flour to the yeast mixture. Beat with a mixer or wooden spoon until smooth.
Gradually stir in enough of the remaining flour (1 to 1 1/2 cups) to make a soft dough that pulls away from the sides of the bowl.
Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface and knead for about 5 minutes, until smooth and elastic.
Place the dough in a greased bowl, turning once to coat all sides. Cover with a clean towel and let rise in a warm place until doubled in size, about 1 hour.
Punch down the dough to release air bubbles. At this point, you can shape the rolls in various forms:
FOR CLOVERLEAF ROLLS: Pinch off dough and form into small balls about 1/2 inch in diameter. Place 3 balls in each greased muffin cup.

FOR CRESCENT ROLLS: Roll dough to 1/4-inch thickness and cut into 6-inch circles. Cut each circle into 6-8 wedges. Brush with melted margarine. Starting at the wide end, roll up each wedge and curve into a crescent shape. Place on greased baking sheet.

FOR PARKERHOUSE ROLLS: Roll dough to 1/4-inch thickness. Cut with a 3-inch biscuit cutter. Make a crease just below the center of each circle with a knife handle or spoon. Brush with melted margarine. Fold the top half over the bottom half (bottom should be slightly larger). Place on greased baking sheet.

FOR FANTAN ROLLS: Roll dough into a rectangle about 1/8-inch thick. Cut into 1-inch-wide strips. Brush with melted margarine. Stack 6-7 strips on top of each other. Cut the stack into 1 1/4-inch pieces. Place each piece cut-side up in a greased muffin cup.
Cover shaped rolls and let rise in a warm place until doubled, about 30 minutes.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Bake for 12-15 minutes, or until golden brown.
Brush with additional melted butter if desired. Serve warm.

original_recipe.name: Bean Salad
original_recipe.source: Mrs. Harriet Pooley of Heber Springs, Arkansas
instructions: Drain vegetables, then marinate in a mixture of vinegar, sugar, water, and salad oil.
Note: Vegetable relish salad recipe calls for bringing the marinade to a boil before adding to the vegetables and then refrigerating the salad overnight before serving.

improved_recipe.name: Marinated Three-Bean Salad
instructions: In a large bowl, combine the drained green beans, corn, kidney beans, diced celery, chopped onion, and diced peppers.
In a small saucepan, combine the vinegar, sugar, water, and oil. Bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring until the sugar dissolves.
Pour the hot marinade over the vegetables and toss gently to coat.
Cover and refrigerate for at least 4 hours or overnight, stirring occasionally.
Serve chilled as a side salad or on a bed of lettuce.

original_recipe.name: Blueberry Jello Salad
instructions: FIRST LAYER: Mix 6 ounces of jello with 3 & 1/2 cups of hot water. Put in loaf pan. Chill until very firm.
SECOND LAYER: Heat milk while adding sugar and gelatin (do not boil) until they dissolve. Add vanilla and softened cream cheese. Mix and add nuts. Cool slightly and pour over first layer. Chill.
THIRD LAYER: Add one cup of hot water to regular size (3 oz) of jello, stir well. Add blueberries and juice. Cool slightly and pour over first mixture. Chill until very firm.

improved_recipe.name: Three-Layer Blueberry Jello Salad
instructions: FIRST LAYER: In a large bowl, dissolve the 6-oz family-size raspberry gelatin in 3 1/2 cups boiling water, stirring until completely dissolved. Pour into a 9x13-inch loaf pan or dish and refrigerate until very firm, about 2–3 hours.

SECOND LAYER: In a small bowl, sprinkle the unflavored gelatin over 1/2 cup cold water and let stand 5 minutes to soften. In a small saucepan, heat the milk and sugar over medium-low heat, stirring, until the sugar dissolves. Do not boil. Add the softened unflavored gelatin and stir until fully dissolved. Remove from heat and stir in the vanilla. Let cool slightly, then whisk in the softened cream cheese until smooth. Stir in the chopped pecans. Let the mixture cool to lukewarm, then gently pour over the firm first layer. Refrigerate until set, about 1–2 hours.

THIRD LAYER: Dissolve the 3-oz regular-size raspberry gelatin in 1 cup boiling water, stirring well. Gently stir in the blueberries and their juice. Let cool to room temperature, then carefully pour over the second layer. Refrigerate until very firm, at least 2–3 hours or overnight.
To serve, cut into squares and serve on lettuce leaves if desired. The three distinct layers create a beautiful presentation.

original_recipe.name: Oriental Salad
instructions: Toast almonds and sesame seeds in toaster oven, or saute in sesame oil.
Add these to cole slaw and chopped onions.
Add Ramen noodles (save seasoning packets for use in dressing). Mix well.
Combine dressing ingredients, shake well, pour over above salad and mix well.

improved_recipe.name: Crunchy Oriental Ramen Salad
instructions: In a small skillet, toast the sliced almonds and sesame seeds in the sesame oil over medium heat, stirring frequently, until golden and fragrant, about 3–5 minutes. Set aside to cool.
Break the uncooked Ramen noodles into small pieces (discard the seasoning packets for now, or save for the dressing).
In a large salad bowl, combine the cole slaw mix, chopped green onions, broken Ramen noodles, toasted almonds, and toasted sesame seeds. Toss to mix.

In a jar or small bowl, combine the safflower or canola oil, rice vinegar, sugar, salt, pepper, and the two Ramen seasoning packets. Shake or whisk vigorously until well blended and the sugar is dissolved.
Just before serving, pour the dressing over the salad and toss well to coat evenly.
Serve immediately for maximum crunch. If making ahead, keep the dressing separate and toss just before serving to prevent the noodles from becoming soggy.

original_recipe.name: Raspberry Jello Salad

ingredients.notes: If fresh, freeze first then cook a little

instructions: Combine two cups of boiling water (mixed with the pineapple and blueberry juices) with the jello.
Add raspberries and pineapple and chill in the refrigerator.
Combine the sour cream, cream cheese and sugar. Mix well.
Spread over the top of the chilled jello mixture.
Sprinkle the nuts over the top.

improved_recipe.name: Raspberry Jello Salad with Creamy Topping

ingredients.notes: or 2 cups fresh, frozen and cooked

instructions: Drain the blueberries and pineapple, reserving the juices. Measure the combined juices and add enough boiling water to make 2 cups total liquid.
In a large bowl, dissolve the raspberry gelatin in the 2 cups of hot juice-water mixture, stirring until completely dissolved.
Stir in the drained blueberries and pineapple tidbits. Pour into a 9x13-inch dish and refrigerate until firm, about 3–4 hours.
In a medium bowl, beat together the sour cream, softened cream cheese, and sugar until smooth and creamy.
Spread the cream cheese mixture evenly over the top of the chilled gelatin layer.
Sprinkle the chopped nuts over the creamy topping.
Refrigerate for at least 1 hour before serving. Cut into squares to serve.

original_recipe.name: Vegetable Relish Salad
instructions: Drain all vegetables in colander with exception of two tablespoons of green bean juice (take from can prior to draining). Save vegetable juices for soup.
Mix all sauce ingredients well.
Bring to a boil, pour over vegetables, stir, then refrigerate overnight before serving.

improved_recipe.name: Vegetable Relish Salad
instructions: Before draining the green beans, reserve 2 tablespoons of the liquid from the can.
Drain all canned vegetables in a colander. You can save the remaining vegetable juices for soup stock if desired.
In a large bowl, combine the drained corn, green beans, peas, chopped onion, celery, green bell pepper, and pimento.
In a small saucepan, combine the sugar, oil, vinegar, salt, pepper, and reserved green bean juice.
Bring the marinade to a boil over medium-high heat, stirring to dissolve the sugar.
Pour the hot marinade over the vegetables and stir gently to coat everything evenly.
Cover and refrigerate overnight (at least 8 hours) to allow the flavors to blend.
Stir before serving. Serve cold as a side dish or relish.
This salad keeps well in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.

original_recipe.name: Carrot Soup
instructions: In heavy saucepan, melt margarine over moderate heat. Stir in celery and onions and cook five minutes until soft but not brown.
Add carrots, chicken broth, tomato paste and rice. Simmer for thirty minutes.
Puree the soup through a food mill or a blender until smooth.
Season and stir into milk. Reheat before serving. Add margarine and garnish with carrot curls.

improved_recipe.name: Creamy Carrot Soup
instructions: In a large heavy saucepan or Dutch oven, melt 2 tablespoons of margarine over medium heat.
Add the chopped onion and celery. Cook, stirring occasionally, for about 5 minutes, until softened but not browned.
Stir in the chopped carrots, chicken broth, tomato paste, and raw rice. Bring to a simmer.
Reduce heat and simmer gently for 30 minutes, or until the carrots and rice are very tender.
Working in batches if necessary, puree the soup in a blender or food processor until completely smooth. Alternatively, use an immersion blender directly in the pot.
Return the pureed soup to the pot (if using a blender). Stir in the evaporated milk and remaining tablespoon of margarine.
Season with salt and white pepper to taste. Reheat gently over low heat; do not boil.
Ladle into bowls and garnish with carrot curls, if desired. Serve hot.

original_recipe.name: Hearty Chowder
instructions: Pre-cook the potatoes and carrots (separately-carrots take longer to cook) until almost done in boiling salted water. Drain.
Meanwhile, melt margarine in heavy kettle or dutch oven. Add turkey ham and garlic and cook over low heat for about five minutes.
Add celery broccoli and onions and continue to cook over low heat until vegetables are soft but not brown.
Blend flour, ham, garlic, celery broccoli and onions. Add milk slowly; continue to cook and stir until mixture is smooth and thickened.
Add potatoes and carrots. Adjust seasoning.
Cover and cook over very low heat (DO NOT LET COME TO A BOIL) until chowder is piping hot and carrots are tender.

improved_recipe.name: Hearty Turkey and Vegetable Chowder

ingredients.item: Salt and freshly ground black pepper

instructions: Bring a pot of lightly salted water to a boil. Add the diced carrots and cook for about 5 minutes. Add the cubed potatoes and cook for another 5–7 minutes, until both are just tender. Drain and set aside.
In a large heavy pot or Dutch oven, melt the margarine over medium-low heat.
Add the cubed turkey ham and minced garlic. Cook, stirring occasionally, for about 5 minutes.
Stir in the celery, broccoli (if using), and chopped onion. Continue cooking over low heat, stirring occasionally, until the vegetables are soft but not browned (about 5–7 minutes).
Sprinkle the flour over the vegetable and ham mixture. Stir well to coat everything evenly, and cook for 1–2 minutes to remove the raw flour taste.
Gradually pour in the milk, whisking or stirring constantly to prevent lumps. Cook over medium heat, stirring frequently, until the mixture is smooth and begins to thicken.
Add the cooked potatoes and carrots. Stir gently to combine.
Season with salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.
Reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer gently for about 10 minutes to let the flavors meld. Do not let the chowder boil, or the milk may curdle.
Serve hot, with crackers or crusty bread on the side.

original_recipe.name: Divinity
original_recipe.subtitle: A favorite recipe of Alma Finken Carle
instructions: Cook sugar, water, and corn syrup over low heat, stirring until sugar is dissolved.
Continue to cook without stirring until the hard-ball stage has been reached (Alma prefers 265° F).
Meanwhile, beat the egg whites with an electric mixer until stiff.
Pour the hot syrup over the stiffened egg whites gradually, while continuing to beat.
Beat at medium speed until mixture begins to thicken.
Add vanilla and nuts and pour onto a pan that has been coated with a nonstick vegetable spray.
Cut into squares when cool. As an alternative, line pan with wax paper. Then drop mixture from spoon onto wax paper. Let cool.

improved_recipe.name: Divinity
instructions: Line a baking sheet with wax paper or parchment, or coat an 8×8-inch pan with nonstick spray.
In a heavy 2-quart saucepan, combine the sugar, corn syrup, and water. Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, until the sugar dissolves.
Once the sugar is dissolved, stop stirring. Continue cooking without stirring until the mixture reaches 265°F (hard-ball stage) on a candy thermometer. This will take 10-15 minutes.
While the syrup cooks, beat the egg whites in a large bowl with an electric mixer on high speed until stiff peaks form.
When the syrup reaches 265°F, remove it from heat. With the mixer running on medium speed, slowly pour the hot syrup in a thin stream into the beaten egg whites. Be careful—the mixture is very hot.
Continue beating at medium speed until the mixture becomes thick and starts to lose its gloss, about 5-8 minutes.
Stir in the flavoring extract and chopped nuts by hand.
Quickly drop spoonfuls of the mixture onto the prepared wax paper, or spread into the prepared pan and cut into squares when cool.
Let cool completely at room temperature. Store in an airtight container.

original_recipe.name: Fudge (Cocoa Nut)
original_recipe.subtitle: Cook to soft-ball stage without stirring
instructions: Combine sugar, cocoa powder, and milk in a saucepan. Cook, stirring, until sugar is dissolved.
Continue to cook over very, very low heat until the soft-ball stage has been reached (234° F to 238° F). DO NOT STIR WHILE COOKING!
Add margarine and set aside. When almost cool (lukewarm), add vanilla and beat until creamy.
Stir in the nuts. Pour onto a pan that has been coated with a nonstick vegetable spray.
When quite cool, cut into squares. Yield: 1 cup. 55 calories per tablespoon.

improved_recipe.name: Cocoa Nut Fudge
instructions: Line an 8×8-inch pan with foil or parchment, or coat it with nonstick spray.
In a heavy 2-quart saucepan, combine the sugar, cocoa powder, and milk. Stir over medium heat until the sugar dissolves and the mixture is smooth.

Once the sugar is dissolved, clip a candy thermometer to the side of the pan. Stop stirring and cook without stirring over very low heat until the mixture reaches soft-ball stage (234-238°F). This will take 20-30 minutes.
Remove from heat and add the margarine. Do not stir—just let it melt on top.
Let the mixture cool undisturbed to lukewarm (about 110°F), about 30-45 minutes.
Add the vanilla and beat vigorously with a wooden spoon until the fudge thickens and loses its gloss, about 5-10 minutes.
Stir in the chopped nuts.
Quickly pour the fudge into the prepared pan and smooth the top.
Let cool completely, then cut into squares. Store in an airtight container.

original_recipe.name: Peanut Brittle (Munching)
original_recipe.subtitle: Microwave preparation
instructions: Combine salt, sugar, syrup, and peanuts in a 1 & 1/2 quart casserole. Stir well.
Microwave on HIGH for 4 minutes. Stir well, and microwave an additional 3 to 5 minutes until light brown.
Add and blend well into the syrup: margarine and vanilla. Microwave on HIGH for 1 or 2 minutes more. Peanuts will be light brown and syrup very hot.
Add one teaspoon of baking soda and gently stir until hot and foamy.
Pour mixture onto cookie sheet that has been coated with a nonstick vegetable spray, or un-buttered non-stick coated cookie sheet.
Let cool 1/2 to 1 hour. When cool, break into small pieces and store in airtight container.
Variation: For PECAN BRITTLE, use 1 & 1/2 cups of pecan halves instead of peanuts and use coconut extract in place of vanilla extract.

improved_recipe.name: Microwave Peanut Brittle
instructions: Coat a large rimmed baking sheet with nonstick spray or use a nonstick baking mat.
In a microwave-safe 1 1/2-quart or 2-quart glass bowl, stir together the sugar, corn syrup, salt, and peanuts until well combined.
Microwave on HIGH for 4 minutes.
Remove and stir well. Microwave on HIGH for an additional 3-5 minutes, until the mixture turns light golden brown and the peanuts are toasted. Watch carefully to avoid burning.
Carefully remove from microwave (mixture will be extremely hot). Stir in the margarine and vanilla until well blended.
Microwave on HIGH for 1-2 minutes more, until the syrup is very hot and the peanuts are golden.
Immediately stir in the baking soda—the mixture will foam up dramatically. Stir quickly until well mixed and foamy.
Quickly pour the hot mixture onto the prepared baking sheet and spread as thin as possible with a greased spatula.
Let cool completely, about 30-60 minutes.
Break into pieces and store in an airtight container. For Pecan Brittle, substitute 1 1/2 cups pecan halves for peanuts and coconut extract for vanilla.

original_recipe.name: Pralines, Old Fashioned
original_recipe.subtitle: Buttermilk-based praline recipe
instructions: Combine first six ingredients in a large, heavy saucepan.
Cook over low heat, stirring gently, until sugar dissolves.
Cover, and cook over medium heat 2 to 3 minutes to wash down sugar crystals from side of pan.
Uncover, and cook to soft ball stage (234° F to 238° F) stirring constantly.
Remove from heat, and stir in soda and vanilla.
Beat with a wooden spoon just until mixture begins to thicken.
Working rapidly, drop by tablespoons onto wax paper that has been coated with a nonstick vegetable spray; let stand until firm.
Yield 1 & 1/2 to 2 dozen.

improved_recipe.name: Old-Fashioned Buttermilk Pralines
instructions: Line 2 baking sheets with wax paper or parchment, and lightly coat with nonstick spray.
In a large, heavy saucepan (at least 3-quart), combine the granulated sugar, brown sugar, pecans, buttermilk, margarine, and salt.
Cook over low heat, stirring gently, until both sugars dissolve completely.
Cover the pan and cook over medium heat for 2-3 minutes. This creates steam that washes sugar crystals off the sides of the pan.
Uncover and clip a candy thermometer to the side. Cook, stirring constantly, until the mixture reaches soft-ball stage (234-238°F). This will take about 10-15 minutes.
Remove from heat. Stir in the baking soda and vanilla—the mixture will foam up.
Beat vigorously with a wooden spoon until the mixture begins to thicken and lose its gloss, about 2-3 minutes.
Working quickly, drop tablespoonfuls of the mixture onto the prepared wax paper, spacing them about 2 inches apart.
Let the pralines cool completely until firm, about 30 minutes. Store in an airtight container with wax paper between layers.

original_recipe.name: Fudge (Plain)
instructions: Combine sugar, cocoa powder, salt and milk in a saucepan.
Heat slowly, stirring constantly, until sugar is dissolved.
Cook to the soft-ball stage, 234° F to 238° F. DO NOT STIR WHILE COOKING!
Stir in margarine and oil and cool to lukewarm.
Add vanilla and beat with a spoon until the mixture is almost stiff.
Pour onto a pan that has been coated with a nonstick vegetable spray.
Cool, and cut into squares.

improved_recipe.name: Classic Chocolate Fudge
instructions: Lightly coat an 8x8-inch baking pan with nonstick cooking spray or line with parchment paper.
In a heavy-bottomed saucepan, combine the sugar, cocoa powder, salt, and milk. Stir well to mix.
Place the saucepan over medium-low heat. Stir constantly until the sugar is completely dissolved and the mixture is smooth.

Once the sugar dissolves, stop stirring. Attach a candy thermometer to the side of the pan. Continue cooking without stirring until the mixture reaches the soft-ball stage (234-238°F). This may take 15-20 minutes. Be patient and do not stir during this time, or the fudge may crystallize.
When the mixture reaches the soft-ball stage, remove from heat immediately. Stir in the margarine and oil.
Let the mixture cool, undisturbed, to lukewarm (about 110°F). This may take 30-45 minutes. Do not stir during cooling, or the fudge may become grainy.
Once lukewarm, add the vanilla extract. Beat vigorously with a wooden spoon until the mixture thickens and loses its glossy appearance. This can take 5-10 minutes of beating.
Quickly pour the fudge into the prepared pan and spread evenly with a spatula.
Let the fudge cool completely at room temperature until firm, about 2 hours.
Cut into 1-inch squares. Store in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 2 weeks.

original_recipe.name: Apple Cake
instructions: This is a very stiff dough!
Bake thirty to forty minutes at 350° F.

improved_recipe.name: Old-Fashioned Apple Cake
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease and flour a 9x13-inch baking pan.
In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, cinnamon, and salt.
In a large bowl, beat the eggs. Add both sugars, the oil, and vanilla, and mix until well combined.
Stir the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients until just combined. The batter will be very thick and stiff.
Fold in the diced apples and chopped pecans, distributing them evenly.
Spread the thick batter into the prepared pan, smoothing the top as well as you can.
Bake for 30–40 minutes, or until the top is golden brown and a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean.
Cool in the pan on a wire rack. Serve warm or at room temperature, plain or with a dusting of powdered sugar or a scoop of vanilla ice cream.

original_recipe.name: Deluxe White Cake
instructions: Pre-heat oven to 350°F. Coat with nonstick vegetable spray and flour three 9" round cake pans.
Sift flour, one cup of sugar, the baking powder, baking soda, and salt into a large bowl.
Beat egg whites until foamy, add cream of tartar, and beat until stiff but not dry.
Add remaining 1/2 cup of sugar to egg whites gradually, beating until meringue is glossy. Set aside for a minute or two.
Combine oil, buttermilk, and vanilla. Stir until well mixed.
Pour this mixture into the dry ingredients all at once and beat into a smooth batter.
Fold in meringue, using a rubber spatula to clean bottom and sides of bowl.
Pour batter into pan which has been coated with a cooking spray.
Bake in the pre-heated oven for thirty to thirty-five minutes, or until just firm to the touch and beginning to leave the sides of the pan.
Leave cake in pan for five minutes, then remove from pans by inverting onto a dish cloth or cake rack.

improved_recipe.name: Deluxe White Layer Cake
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease and flour three 9-inch round cake pans, or line the bottoms with parchment.
In a large bowl, sift together the cake flour, 1 cup of the sugar, the baking powder, baking soda, and salt. Set aside.
In a separate bowl, beat the egg whites until foamy. Add the cream of tartar and continue beating until soft peaks form.
Gradually add the remaining 1/2 cup of sugar to the egg whites, beating until the meringue is stiff and glossy. Set aside.
In another bowl, whisk together the oil, buttermilk, and vanilla until well combined.
Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients all at once and beat with a mixer on medium speed until you have a smooth batter.
Using a rubber spatula, gently fold the meringue into the batter in three additions, making sure to scrape the bottom and sides of the bowl for even mixing.
Divide the batter evenly among the three prepared pans.
Bake for 30–35 minutes, or until the cakes are just firm to the touch and starting to pull away from the sides of the pans. A toothpick inserted in the center should come out clean.
Let the cakes cool in the pans for 5 minutes, then turn out onto a wire rack to cool completely before frosting.

original_recipe.name: Frosted Carrot Cake

ingredients.quantity: 8 oz can in own juice, drained

instructions: Combine first five ingredients; set aside.
Combine brown sugar and next seven ingredients in a large mixing bowl; stir in dry ingredients and beat at medium speed with an electric mixer until well blended.
Pour batter into a 13" x 9" x 2" pan that has been coated with a nonstick vegetable spray.
Bake at 350° F for 30 to 35 minutes or until a wooden pick inserted in center comes out clean.
Cool cake completely in pan on wire rack.
Spread Orange-Cream Frosting (see Frosting section for recipe) on top of cake.
Cover and chill. Yield: 18 servings.

improved_recipe.name: Frosted Carrot Cake with Orange-Cream Cheese Frosting

ingredients.quantity: 8 oz can in juice, well drained

instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Coat a 13x9x2-inch baking pan with nonstick spray.
In a medium bowl, whisk together the all-purpose flour, whole wheat flour, baking soda, cinnamon, and salt.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the brown sugar, eggs or egg substitute, buttermilk, oil, and vanilla. Beat at medium speed until smooth.
Add the drained pineapple, grated carrots, and raisins to the wet mixture and stir to combine.
Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and beat just until well blended and no dry pockets remain.
Pour the batter into the prepared pan and spread evenly.
Bake for 30–35 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean and the top springs back when lightly touched.
Cool the cake completely in the pan on a wire rack.
Once cooled, spread Orange-Cream Cheese Frosting evenly over the top of the cake.
Cover and refrigerate for at least 1 hour before serving. Cut into squares to serve.

original_recipe.name: Bakeless Fruit Cake
instructions: Reserve 40 pecan halves to place on top of cake; chop remaining pecans, and set aside.
Combine vanilla wafers and graham crackers in a large mixing bowl.
Stir in raisins, dates, cherries, and reserved chopped nuts, mixing well.
Add sweetened condensed milk and bourbon whiskey; stir well.
Line a 9 x 5 x 3 inch loaf pan with waxed paper allowing enough paper to cover the top (Handi-wrap does a better job and is easier to work with).
Press the cake mixture tightly into the pan.
Arrange reserved pecan halves on top.
Cover cake with excess paper and chill overnight.
Slice and serve with whipped cream.

improved_recipe.name: No-Bake Holiday Fruit Cake
instructions: Reserve 40 whole pecan halves for decorating the top. Coarsely chop the remaining pecans.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the crushed vanilla wafers and crushed graham crackers.
Add the raisins, chopped dates, chopped cherries, and chopped pecans. Mix well to distribute evenly.
Pour in the sweetened condensed milk and bourbon (or rum). Stir thoroughly until the mixture is well combined and holds together.
Line a 9x5x3-inch loaf pan with plastic wrap or waxed paper, leaving enough overhang to cover the top.
Spoon the mixture into the prepared pan and press down very firmly and evenly to compact it.
Arrange the reserved pecan halves decoratively on top, pressing them lightly into the surface.
Fold the excess wrap over the top to cover completely.
Refrigerate overnight, or at least 8 hours, to set.
To serve, unwrap and invert onto a serving platter. Remove the wrap and slice with a sharp knife.
Serve slices plain or with a dollop of whipped cream. Store wrapped in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.

original_recipe.name: Hot Water Gingerbread
instructions: Mix sugar and molasses with melted margarine; add eggs and mix well.
Mix dry ingredients and add to first mixture; add hot water and beat thoroughly.
Place in baking pan (2" x 10" x 13") that has been coated with a nonstick vegetable spray and bake for fifty minutes at 350° F.

improved_recipe.name: Moist Hot Water Gingerbread
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease a 9x13-inch baking pan or coat with nonstick spray.
In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, ginger, cinnamon, and salt.
In a separate large bowl, combine the molasses, sugar, and melted margarine or butter. Mix well.
Add the egg to the molasses mixture and beat until smooth.
Add the dry ingredients to the wet mixture and stir until just combined.
Carefully stir in the boiling water. The batter will be thin—this is correct.
Pour the batter into the prepared pan.
Bake for 45-50 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean and the top springs back when lightly touched.
Cool in the pan on a wire rack for at least 15 minutes.
Serve warm or at room temperature, plain or with whipped cream or lemon sauce.

original_recipe.name: Spice Cake
instructions: At Christmas time, add nuts and fruit peels to convert to a fruit cake.
Blend oil, sugar and water.
Stir in flour and remaining ingredients.
Bake at 350° F for 30 or 40 minutes.
Grandmother baked this cake in a heavy cake pan or an iron skillet.
Eggs WERE NOT USED. Cake was not iced.
*Note: Grandmother Walters used 1/2 cup of shortening, probably lard.

improved_recipe.name: Old-Fashioned Eggless Spice Cake
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease a 9-inch square or round cake pan or an 8-inch cast iron skillet.
In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, cocoa powder, baking soda, cinnamon, nutmeg, ginger, and salt.
In a separate bowl or measuring cup, combine the vegetable oil and water.
Pour the liquid mixture into the dry ingredients and stir just until combined.
Fold in the raisins.
Pour the batter into the prepared pan.
Bake for 30-40 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean.
Cool in the pan on a wire rack.
Serve plain, as Grandmother did, or dust lightly with powdered sugar if desired.
Note: For a Christmas fruitcake variation, add 1/2 cup chopped nuts and 1/2 cup chopped candied fruit or peel to the batter.

original_recipe.name: Old Fashioned Jelly Roll
instructions: Sift flour once, measure.
Combine baking powder, salt, and eggs in bowl.
Place over smaller bowl of hot water and beat, adding sugar gradually until mixture becomes thick and light colored.
Remove bowl from hot water.
Fold in flour and vanilla.
Turn into a 15" x 10" pan that has been coated with a nonstick vegetable oil and lined with greased paper.
Bake in hot oven at 400° F for 13 minutes.
Quickly cut off crisp edges of cake.
Turn from pan at once onto cloth covered with powdered sugar.
Remove paper.
Spread with jelly and roll.
Wrap in cloth and cool on rack.
For a moist butter sponge roll, fold 2 tablespoons of melted margarine into batter before turning into pan.

improved_recipe.name: Classic Jelly Roll Sponge Cake
instructions: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Grease a 15x10-inch jelly roll pan, line with parchment paper, and grease the paper.
In a small bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder, and salt. Set aside.
Place the eggs in a large heatproof bowl. Set the bowl over a pot of simmering water (double boiler method).
Beat the eggs with an electric mixer while gradually adding the sugar. Continue beating over the hot water until the mixture is very thick, pale, and tripled in volume (about 5-7 minutes).
Remove the bowl from the heat.
Gently fold in the vanilla extract.
Sift the flour mixture over the egg mixture in three additions, folding gently after each addition until just combined. Do not overmix.
If making a richer version, fold in 2 tablespoons melted margarine or butter at this point.
Pour the batter into the prepared pan and spread evenly to the edges.
Bake for 12-13 minutes, until the cake is golden and springs back when lightly touched.
While the cake bakes, lay out a clean kitchen towel and dust it generously with confectioners' sugar.
When the cake is done, immediately run a knife around the edges and invert the cake onto the sugared towel.
Carefully peel off the parchment paper. Trim any crisp edges with a sharp knife.
Starting from a short end, roll the cake up in the towel while it's still warm. Let cool completely on a wire rack, seam-side down.
Once cooled, gently unroll the cake and spread evenly with your favorite jelly or jam.
Re-roll the cake without the towel, and place seam-side down on a serving platter.
Dust with additional confectioners' sugar before slicing and serving.

original_recipe.name: Holiday Jam Cake
instructions: Cream butter and sugar.
Beat egg yolks until thick and pale in color (if egg substitute, use 'as is') and add to creamed butter and sugar.
Dissolve soda in buttermilk; beat into butter, egg, and sugar mixture.
Gradually add flour, spices, and jam, alternating jam with dry ingredients.
Fold in stiffly beaten egg whites by hand (if egg substitute was used, you will have to take the whites from 3 eggs).
Roll fruit and nuts in a little flour and add to batter.
Line bottom of a large tube pan with heavy brown paper.
Coat the pan and liner with a nonstick vegetable spray and flour well.
Bake in preheated 300° F oven for 3 to 3 1/2 hours. Test with toothpick or broom straw.
Invert on rack to cool.
When thoroughly cool, cake may be stored in a tin box with apples or wrapped in a soft cloth sprinkled with bourbon, brandy, or sherry.
It is better when aged and will keep in a cool spot for 6 weeks.

improved_recipe.name: Traditional Holiday Jam Cake
instructions: Preheat oven to 300°F (150°C). Line the bottom of a 10-inch tube pan with parchment or heavy brown paper, then grease and flour the pan and paper well.
In a large bowl, cream together the margarine or butter and sugar until light and fluffy.
If using whole eggs, separate them. Beat the egg yolks (or use egg substitute) until thick and pale, then add to the creamed mixture and beat well.
In a small bowl, dissolve the baking soda in the buttermilk. Add this to the creamed mixture and beat until combined.
In a separate bowl, whisk together the flour, cinnamon, nutmeg, cloves, and allspice.
Alternately add the dry ingredients and the blackberry jam to the batter, beginning and ending with the dry ingredients. Mix just until combined after each addition.
If using whole eggs, beat the egg whites in a clean bowl until stiff peaks form. Gently fold the beaten egg whites into the batter by hand.
In a small bowl, toss the pecans, raisins, and dates with 2-3 tablespoons of flour to coat. Fold the floured fruit and nuts into the batter.
Pour the batter into the prepared tube pan and smooth the top.
Bake for 3 to 3 1/2 hours, or until a toothpick or broom straw inserted in the center comes out clean.
Cool in the pan for 15 minutes, then invert onto a wire rack to cool completely.
When completely cool, wrap the cake in a bourbon-, brandy-, or sherry-soaked cloth, or store in an airtight tin with apple slices to keep it moist.
This cake improves with age and will keep in a cool place for up to 6 weeks.

original_recipe.name: Cocoanut Cake
instructions: Bake Deluxe White Cake according to recipe directions in two 9-inch round pans. Cool completely.
In a mixing bowl, cream together confectioners' sugar and softened butter or margarine until light and fluffy.
Gradually add milk and vanilla extract, beating until smooth and spreadable. Add more milk if needed for desired consistency.
Place one cake layer on a serving plate. Spread with a layer of icing.
Sprinkle coconut generously over the icing on the first layer.
Place the second cake layer on top. Frost the top and sides of the cake with the remaining icing.
Press shredded coconut onto the top and sides of the cake, covering completely.
Refrigerate until serving time.

improved_recipe.name: Coconut Layer Cake

ingredients.notes: or your favorite white cake, baked in two 9-inch round pans and cooled

instructions: Bake the Deluxe White Cake (or your favorite white cake recipe) in two greased and floured 9-inch round cake pans according to the recipe directions. Let cool in the pans for 10 minutes, then turn out onto wire racks to cool completely.
While the cakes cool, prepare the buttercream icing: In a large bowl, beat the softened butter or margarine with an electric mixer until creamy.
Gradually add the sifted confectioners' sugar, about 1 cup at a time, beating on low speed after each addition.
Add the milk and vanilla extract. Beat on medium-high speed for 2–3 minutes until the icing is light, fluffy, and spreadable. If the icing is too thick, add a little more milk, 1 teaspoon at a time.
Place one cake layer on a serving plate or cake stand. Spread about 1/2 cup of the icing evenly over the top.
Sprinkle about 1/2 to 3/4 cup of the shredded coconut over the icing on the first layer.
Carefully place the second cake layer on top, pressing gently to adhere.
Frost the top of the cake with a generous layer of icing, then frost the sides, using an offset spatula or butter knife for a smooth finish.

While the icing is still soft, gently press the remaining shredded coconut onto the top and sides of the cake, covering it completely. You may need to work in sections and press the coconut gently with your hands.
Refrigerate the cake for at least 1 hour before serving to let the icing set.
Store leftover cake covered in the refrigerator for up to 4 days. Bring to room temperature before serving for best flavor and texture.

original_recipe.name: Crumble Cake (Krumelkuchen)
instructions: Step 1 (Crust): Blend dry ingredients. Add margarine, eggs, and milk. Mix well. Divide into six portions. Roll each portion out to a size to fit an eight-inch pie plate; about 3/4" up the side.

Step 2 (Crumbles): Blend and mix sugar, vanilla, eggs, margarine, and baking powder well. Work enough flour into mixture until crumbles form. They should be random size with largest about the size of a blueberry.
Step 3 (Binder): Mix eggs, milk, vanilla, and sugar well, then spread four teaspoonfuls of binder evenly on top of each crust before adding crumbles.
Add crumbles to each shell as evenly as possible.
Bake at 350° F for twenty to thirty minutes until nicely browned.

improved_recipe.name: German Crumble Cake (Krümelkuchen)

ingredients.notes: for crust, or 1/2 cup egg substitute
for crumble topping, or 1/2 cup egg substitute
for binder, or 1/2 cup egg substitute

instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Lightly grease six 8-inch pie plates or cake pans.

Prepare the crust: In a large bowl, whisk together 2 cups flour, 2 tsp baking powder, and 1/4 tsp salt. Add the melted margarine, 2/3 cup sugar, 2 eggs (or substitute), and 1/4 cup milk. Mix well until a soft dough forms.
Divide the dough into 6 equal portions. Roll out each portion on a lightly floured surface to fit an 8-inch pie plate, bringing the dough about 3/4 inch up the sides. Press into the prepared pans.
Prepare the crumble topping: In a medium bowl, combine 2 cups sugar, 1 tsp vanilla, 2 eggs (or substitute), 12 tbsp softened margarine, and 2 tsp baking powder. Mix well.
Gradually work in 2 1/2 cups flour, mixing and rubbing with your fingers until crumbles form. The crumbles should be random in size, with the largest about the size of a blueberry.
Prepare the binder: In a small bowl, whisk together 2 eggs (or substitute), 1/4 cup milk, 1 tsp vanilla, and 1 tsp sugar until well combined.
Brush or spoon about 4 teaspoons of the binder mixture evenly over each crust.
Distribute the crumbles evenly over the 6 crusts, dividing them as equally as possible.
Bake for 20-30 minutes, or until the cakes are nicely browned and the crumbles are golden and crisp.
Cool in the pans for 10 minutes, then carefully transfer to a wire rack. Serve warm or at room temperature. These cakes are wonderful with coffee or tea!

original_recipe.name: Apple Pie

ingredients.notes: quantity depends on tartness of apples

instructions: Peel, core and dice enough Granny Smith or any other cooking apples to fill crust to 'rounding'. The apples will cook down when the pie is baked.
Put these cut up apples in a large bowl and mix well with the sugar, cornstarch, and cinnamon.
Place this mixture in the 'bottom' crust and spread out evenly. Margarine can be poured over the mixture, if desired.
Put a crust that has been pierced with air holes on top of the pie. Secure it to the 'bottom' crust by using fork prongs or your fingers.
Bake pie at 400° for 15 minutes; reduce temperature to 350° and bake for an additional 45 minutes, or until the crust is brown.
You can test to see if the apples are done by sticking fork prongs through a hole in the top of the pie.

improved_recipe.name: Classic Apple Pie
instructions: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C).
Peel, core, and dice the apples into bite-sized pieces. You should have about 6 cups of diced apples, generously filling the pie crust.
In a large bowl, combine the diced apples with the sugar, cornstarch, and cinnamon. Toss until the apples are evenly coated.
Place one pie crust into a 9-inch pie pan. Pour the apple mixture into the crust, spreading it evenly. If desired, drizzle the melted margarine over the top of the apples.
Cover with the second pie crust. Trim and crimp the edges to seal. Use a knife to cut several small slits or poke holes in the top crust to allow steam to escape.
Place the pie on a baking sheet to catch any drips. Bake at 400°F for 15 minutes.
Reduce the oven temperature to 350°F (175°C) and continue baking for 45-50 minutes, or until the crust is golden brown and the filling is bubbling.
To test doneness, insert a fork through one of the slits to check if the apples are tender.
Cool on a wire rack for at least 2 hours before slicing. Serve warm or at room temperature, optionally with vanilla ice cream or whipped cream.

original_recipe.name: Pie Crust
original_recipe.subtitle: Makes enough for one 2-crust 8" pie or two 1-crust 8" pies
instructions: Sift dry ingredients together into a bowl.
In another bowl, beat oil and milk with a rotary beater or hand mixer until it has a milky appearance.
Make a 'well' in the dry ingredients. Pour the liquids into the 'well' all at once.
Take a fork and slowly work the ingredients together. DO NOT ADD MORE FLOUR!
By hand, work the mixture into a ball.
Place on wax paper. Cover with plastic wrap and roll out to desired size.
Invert, and remove wax paper. Slip crust into pie pan that has been coated with a nonstick vegetable spray and remove plastic wrap.
Bake for ten minutes at 400° F.

improved_recipe.name: Easy Oil Pie Crust
improved_recipe.servings: Makes 2 single crusts or 1 double crust (8-9 inch)
instructions: In a medium bowl, sift together the flour, sugar (if using), salt, and baking soda.
In a small bowl, whisk together the vegetable oil and 4 tablespoons of cold milk with a rotary beater or hand mixer until the mixture is emulsified and has a milky appearance.
Make a well in the center of the dry ingredients and pour in the oil-milk mixture all at once.
Using a fork, gently stir the mixture, working from the center outward, until it begins to come together. Add 1-2 more tablespoons of milk if the dough seems too dry.
Use your hands to gently gather the dough into a ball. Do not overwork or add extra flour.
Divide the dough in half if making two single crusts.
Place one portion of dough between two sheets of waxed paper or parchment paper. Roll out to about 1/8-inch thickness and to fit your pie pan (9-10 inches in diameter).
Carefully peel off the top sheet of paper, then invert the crust into a lightly greased pie pan. Peel off the remaining paper.
Gently press the crust into the pan and trim the edges. Crimp or flute the edge as desired.
For a pre-baked crust: Prick the bottom and sides with a fork. Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 10-12 minutes, or until lightly golden.
For an unbaked crust: Fill and bake according to your pie recipe directions.
Repeat with the second portion of dough if making a two-crust pie.

original_recipe.name: Chocolate Cream Pie
original_recipe.subtitle: Available in 3 sizes: 9-inch, 8-inch, or 6-inch
instructions: Mix sugar, salt, cornstarch, cocoa, and flour in top of double boiler.
Stir in milk and place over boiling water.
Boil for 3 minutes, stirring constantly.
Temper the egg substitute by slowly whisking a small amount of the hot mixture into it, then pour the tempered egg back into the double boiler.
Cook over boiling water for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Blend in margarine and cool thoroughly.
Blend in vanilla extract.
Pour into cooled, baked pie shell.
Finish with meringue topping (see Meringue recipe). Bake according to meringue instructions.

improved_recipe.name: Chocolate Cream Pie

ingredients.notes: reduce to 1 1/4 cups for 8-inch, 5/8 cup for 6-inch
reduce to 1/2 tsp for 8-inch, 1/3 tsp for 6-inch
reduce to 2 tbsp for 8-inch, 1 1/3 tbsp for 6-inch
reduce to 4 tbsp for 8-inch, 2 tbsp for 6-inch
reduce to 1 tbsp for 8-inch, 1/2 tbsp for 6-inch
reduce to 2 cups for 8-inch, 1 1/3 cups for 6-inch; 2% or whole
reduce to 1/2 cup for 8-inch, 1/4 cup for 6-inch; or use 3 egg yolks for 9-inch
reduce to 1 1/2 tsp for 8-inch, 1 tsp for 6-inch
reduce to 1 tsp for 8-inch, 1/2 tsp for 6-inch

instructions: Fill the bottom of a double boiler with water and bring to a simmer.
In the top of the double boiler (off the heat), whisk together the sugar, salt, cornstarch, cocoa powder, and flour until well combined and lump-free.
Gradually whisk in the milk until the mixture is smooth.

Place the top of the double boiler over the simmering water. Cook, stirring constantly, until the mixture comes to a boil and thickens, about 8–10 minutes. Let it boil gently for 3 minutes, continuing to stir.

In a small bowl, lightly beat the egg substitute (or egg yolks). Slowly whisk about 1/2 cup of the hot chocolate mixture into the egg to temper it, then pour the tempered egg back into the double boiler, whisking constantly.
Cook over the simmering water for an additional 10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the filling is thick and glossy.
Remove from heat and stir in the margarine or butter until melted and fully incorporated.
Let the filling cool for about 10–15 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent a skin from forming. When slightly cooled, stir in the vanilla extract.
Pour the chocolate filling into the cooled, baked pie shell. Smooth the top with a spatula.

If topping with meringue: Spread the meringue over the filling while the filling is still warm, sealing the edges to the crust. Bake at 300°F (150°C) for 15–20 minutes until the meringue is lightly golden. Let cool completely before slicing.
If topping with whipped cream: Refrigerate the pie until fully set (at least 3 hours or overnight), then top with whipped cream just before serving.
Store leftovers covered in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

original_recipe.name: Vanilla Cream Pie
original_recipe.subtitle: Available in 3 sizes: 9-inch, 8-inch, or 6-inch
instructions: Mix sugar, salt, cornstarch and flour in top of double boiler.
Stir in milk. Bring to boil over low heat, and boil 3 minutes, stirring constantly.
Remove from heat. Stir a little of the hot mixture into the egg substitute...then blend into hot mixture.
Place over boiling water, and cook 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Blend in margarine. Cool thoroughly.
Blend in vanilla.
Pour into cooled baked pie shell.
Finish with meringue (see recipe).

improved_recipe.name: Classic Vanilla Cream Pie

ingredients.notes: reduce to 1/2 cup for 8-inch, 1/3 cup for 6-inch
reduce to 1/2 tsp for 8-inch, 1/3 tsp for 6-inch
reduce to 2 tbsp for 8-inch, 1 1/3 tbsp for 6-inch
reduce to 1 tbsp for 8-inch, 1/2 tbsp for 6-inch
reduce to 2 cups for 8-inch, 1 1/3 cups for 6-inch; 2% or whole
reduce to 1/2 cup for 8-inch, 1/4 cup for 6-inch; or use 3 egg yolks for 9-inch
reduce to 1 1/2 tsp for 8-inch, 1 tsp for 6-inch
reduce to 1 tsp for 8-inch, 1/2 tsp for 6-inch

instructions: Fill the bottom of a double boiler with water and bring to a simmer.
In the top of the double boiler (off the heat), whisk together the sugar, salt, cornstarch, and flour until well combined and lump-free.
Gradually whisk in the milk until the mixture is smooth.

Place the top of the double boiler over the simmering water. Cook, stirring constantly, until the mixture comes to a boil and thickens, about 8–10 minutes. Let it boil gently for 3 minutes, continuing to stir.

In a small bowl, lightly beat the egg substitute (or egg yolks). Slowly whisk about 1/2 cup of the hot mixture into the egg to temper it, then pour the tempered egg back into the double boiler, whisking constantly.
Cook over the simmering water for an additional 10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the filling is thick and smooth.
Remove from heat and stir in the margarine or butter until melted and fully incorporated.
Let the filling cool for about 10–15 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent a skin from forming. When slightly cooled, stir in the vanilla extract.
Pour the vanilla filling into the cooled, baked pie shell. Smooth the top with a spatula.

If topping with meringue: Spread the meringue over the filling while the filling is still warm, sealing the edges to the crust. Bake at 300°F (150°C) for 15–20 minutes until the meringue is lightly golden. Let cool completely before slicing.
If topping with whipped cream: Refrigerate the pie until fully set (at least 3 hours or overnight), then top with whipped cream just before serving.
Store leftovers covered in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

original_recipe.name: Lemon Meringue Pie
original_recipe.subtitle: 9-inch
instructions: Mix sugar and cornstarch. Stir in boiling water, cook over direct heat, stirring constantly, until mixture thickens and boils.
Set over boiling water and cook 10 minutes longer.
Beat a little of the hot mixture into the egg substitute. Then beat into hot mixture in double-boiler. Cook 5 minutes, stirring constantly.
Remove from over hot water. Blend in margarine, lemon juice, rind. Cool. Pour into cooled baked pie shell.
Cover with meringue. Bake. Serve cool.

For meringue: Beat egg whites until frothy, add cream of tartar, and continue beating until stiff enough to hold a point. Gradually beat in sugar...continuing beating until mixture is stiff and glossy.
Pile meringue lightly on cooled pie filling...seal it onto edge of crust to prevent shrinking. Swirl or pull up points to make it look decorative.
Bake 15 to 20 minutes at 350° F until meringue is golden brown.

improved_recipe.name: Classic Lemon Meringue Pie
instructions: Prepare the lemon filling: In a medium saucepan, whisk together the 1 1/2 cups sugar and cornstarch.
Gradually stir in the 1 1/2 cups boiling water. Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, until the mixture thickens and comes to a boil.
Transfer the mixture to the top of a double boiler set over simmering water. Cook for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
In a small bowl, lightly beat the egg yolks or egg substitute. Slowly whisk about 1/2 cup of the hot sugar mixture into the eggs to temper them.
Pour the tempered egg mixture back into the double boiler, whisking constantly. Cook for 5 more minutes, stirring constantly, until thick.
Remove from heat. Stir in the margarine, lemon juice, and lemon zest until the margarine is melted and everything is well combined.
Let the filling cool for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally. Pour into the cooled, pre-baked pie shell. Set aside while you make the meringue.
Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C).
Make the meringue: In a clean, dry bowl, beat the egg whites with an electric mixer until foamy. Add the cream of tartar.

Continue beating on high speed until soft peaks form. Gradually add the 6 tablespoons sugar, one tablespoon at a time, beating constantly until stiff, glossy peaks form. The meringue should stand up straight when the beaters are lifted.
Spread the meringue over the warm (not hot) lemon filling, making sure to seal the meringue all the way to the edge of the crust. This prevents shrinking. Swirl or create peaks for a decorative look.
Bake for 15-20 minutes, or until the meringue is golden brown on the peaks.
